{{lang|ar|محمد حسين العمودي}} | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1947 | birth_place = [[Woldia]], [[Ethiopia]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]] | nationality = Ethiopian, Saudi | ethnicity = | education = | occupation = | salary = | children = 8 | parents = | relatives = | website = | restingplace = | alma mater = | networth = US$10.6 billion (January 2018){{cite web|title=Mohammed Al Amoudi|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/mohammed-al-amoudi/|website=Forbes|accessdate=8 January 2018}} | spouse = }} '''Mohammed Hussein Ali Al-'Amoudi''' ({{lang-am|ሞሐመድ አልዐሙዲ}}, {{lang-ar|محمد حسين علي العمودي}}) is an Ethiopian and Saudi Arabian [[billionaire]] businessman. He was born in Ethiopia in 1946 to a Yemeni father and an Ethiopian mother.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/mohammed-al-amoudi/|title=Mohammed Al Amoudi|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en}} In 2016, his net worth was estimated by ''[[Forbes]]'' at approximately $10.9 billion and a relative fall in net value was linked to the global fall in oil and gold prices at the time of estimation. He was also listed as Ethiopia's richest man, the second richest Saudi Arabian citizen in the world and the second richest black person in the world.{{cite web | first=Mfonobong | last=Nsehe | title=The Black Billionaires 2013 | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2013/03/05/the-black-billionaires-2013/ | work=[[Forbes]] | date=5 March 2013 | accessdate=24 March 2013 }} Al Amoudi made his fortune in construction and [[real estate]] before branching out to buy [[oil refineries]] in Sweden and Morocco. He is the largest individual foreign investor in Ethiopia and a major investor in Sweden. ==Business activities== Al Amoudi owns a broad portfolio of businesses in construction, energy, agriculture, mining, hotels, healthcare and manufacturing amongst others. His businesses are largely to be found within two [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]] [[holding company|holding]] and operating companies, [[Corral Petroleum Holdings]] and [[MIDROC]], both which he owns and manages. He employs over 70,000 people through these companies.{{cite web|url=http://www.sheikhmohammedalamoudi.info |title=Home - Sheikh Al Amoudi | Authorized & Official |publisher=Sheikhmohammedalamoudi.info |date= |accessdate=12 August 2015}} Al Amoudi's construction company consortium, ''Mohammed International Development Research and Organization Companies'', also known as MIDROC, won a contract to build Saudi Arabia's estimated $30 billion nationwide [[underground oil storage]] complex in 1988. MIDROC acquired Yanbu Steel in Saudi Arabia in 2000.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bus-ex.com/article/yanbu-steel-company |title=Yanbu Steel Company | Business Excellence Magazine |publisher=Bus-ex.com |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} In addition to his business interests in Ethiopia, he also owns oil refineries in [[Morocco]] and [[Sweden]] ([[Svenska Petroleum Exploration AB]]) and is engaged in [[energy exploration]] and production off West Africa and elsewhere.[http://www.pr-inside.com/new-market-report-svenska-petroleum-exploration-r2542679.htm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614091935/http://www.pr-inside.com/new-market-report-svenska-petroleum-exploration-r2542679.htm|date=14 June 2012}} His [[Addis Ababa]] [[Sheraton Hotels and Resorts|Sheraton]] is said to be among the finest hotels in Africa.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/mohammed-al-amoudi |title=Mohammed Al Amoudi |publisher=Forbes |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} He has recently pledged US$275 million alongside other Saudi and South Korean investors through MIDROC to finance a factory to build Saudi Arabia's first car, to be called [[KSU Gazal-1|Gazal-1]], in a project initiated by [[King Saud University]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewiStockNews/articleid/4774278|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230233319/http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewiStockNews/articleid/4774278|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-12-30|title=KSU mobilizes $500 million for new car company|date=2010-12-30|access-date=2018-06-12}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-29/midroc-to-get-55-of-saudi-car-plant-for-275-million-spa-says.html |title=Midroc to Get 55% of Saudi Car Plant for $275 Million, SPA Says - Bloomberg Business |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=29 December 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} and, in September 2011, it was announced that he planned to invest around US$1.07bn (4bn Saudi Riyals) in two major Saudi industrial projects (phosphate derivatives and sulfur) in [[Ras Al Khair]] [Eastern Region] and [[Jubail Industrial City]] respectively.[http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZW20110929000084]{{dead link|date=August 2015}} ===Ethiopian investments=== Al Amoudi has invested in Ethiopia since the mid-1980s. He now has business interests there, largely operated through MIDROC Ethiopia which was created in 1994. In 2011 it made 1.4bn birr (US$70m) of profits.{{cite web|url=http://www.2merkato.com/20111014451/midroc-ethiopia-announces-13-billion-birr-profit |title=Ethiopia Earns $71.1 Million From Leather Exports |publisher=2merkato.com |date= |accessdate=12 August 2015}} === Natural resources === He has [[gold mining]] interests in Ethiopia[http://www.newsdire.com/business/1685-egyptian-mining-company-hit-immense-gold-reserve.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113151324/http://www.newsdire.com/business/1685-egyptian-mining-company-hit-immense-gold-reserve.html|date=13 January 2012}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-12/ethiopia-aiming-to-license-50-mineral-projects-every-year-boost-exports.html |title=Ethiopia Aiming to License 50 Mineral Projects Every Year - Bloomberg Business |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=12 November 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} and it is reported that MIDROC Gold Mine (a subsidiary of MIDROC Ethiopia) has paid the Ethiopian Government 100.1 million birr in royalties, the largest contribution of any mining company.[http://addisfortune.com/Second%20Largest%20Nickel%20Producer%20Sets%20up%20Shop%20in%20Konso.htm]{{dead link|date=August 2015}} Midroc Gold is Ethiopia’s sole gold exporter. Its [[Lega Dembi mine]] has a yearly average production of around 4,500 kg of gold and silver.[http://addisfortune.com/Artisan%20Miners%20Surpass%20Expectation%20after%20109-5m%20Gold%20Sale.htm]{{dead link|date=August 2015}} He owns 70% of [[National Oil Ethiopia]], which competes with [[Yetebaberut Beherawi Petroleum|YBF]], [[TAF OIL]] and five other companies in the national petrol market[http://addisfortune.com/TAF%20Joins%20Tough%20Competition%20in%20Oil%20Market.htm]{{dead link|date=August 2015}} and is establishing a steel plant (Tossa) in [[Amhara Region|Amhara]]. This latter is Ethiopia’s first industrial steel production plant and in intended to meet a major increase in domestic demand, estimated to rise from 1.2m tonnes to 3.1m tonnes per annum between 2011 and 2014.{{cite web|url=http://addisfortune.com/Bidding%20for%201.3m%20tones%20Steel%20Factory%20Sees%20Nine%20Interest.htm |accessdate=27 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103195730/http://www.addisfortune.com/Bidding%20for%201.3m%20tones%20Steel%20Factory%20Sees%20Nine%20Interest.htm |archivedate=3 November 2011 }} In February 2011, Al Amoudi acquired 69% of Ethiopia’s sole tyre manufacturer [[Addis Tyre]]{{cite web |url=http://addisfortune.com/Al-Amoudi%E2%80%99s%20Horizon%20Acquires%20Matador-ATC%E2%80%99s%2069pc%20for%20$18m.htm |accessdate=2 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110211104613/http://www.addisfortune.com/Al-Amoudi%E2%80%99s%20Horizon%20Acquires%20Matador-ATC%E2%80%99s%2069pc%20for%20%2418m.htm |archivedate=11 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and he has a substantial investment in cement production through [[Durba]] Midroc which was founded in 2008.[http://addisfortune.com/EEPCo%20Grants%20Cement%20Factory%20Own%20Power%20Station.htm]{{dead link|date=August 2015}} His major cement plant near Chancho was backed in part by the World Bank’s International Finance Corporation.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-20/ethiopian-cement-plants-to-double-capacity-amid-construction-industry-boom.html |title=Ethiopian Cement Plants to Double Capacity Amid Building Boom - Bloomberg Business |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2015}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.addisfortune.com/Derba%20Midroc%20Wants%2050MW%20for%20Factory.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521045939/http://www.addisfortune.com/Derba%20Midroc%20Wants%2050MW%20for%20Factory.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-05-21|title=Derba Midroc Wants 50MW for Factory|date=2011-05-21|access-date=2018-06-12}} In July 2011, it was announced that the Ethiopian Electric Power Company [EEPco] would provide the Derba cement plant with 50MW of electricity. === Agriculture === The Al Amoudi-owned ''Saudi Star Agricultural Development'' Plc plans to [[Land development|develop]] up to {{convert|500000|ha|acre}} of Ethiopian land for sugar, [[edible oil]], and grain production.{{cite web|url=https://www.sheikhmohammedalamoudi.info/backgrounders/saudi-star-agribusiness|title=Official Web Site: Saudi Star Page}} In March 2011, Saudi Star announced a further investment of $2.5 billion in Ethiopian rice projects.{{cite web|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2011032496586 |title=Al-Amoudi to invest $2.5b in Ethiopia farm | Business |publisher=Saudi Gazette |date= |accessdate=12 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003183339/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2011032496586 |archivedate=3 October 2015 |df=dmy }} Some 10,000 hectares have been taken up in 60-year leases and the company plans to rent an additional 290,000 hectares. The company had reportedly purchased $80 million in equipment from [[Caterpillar Inc]].{{cite web|last=McLure |first=Jason |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aIFZN6VBgYR4 |title=Saudi Billionaire Invests in Ethiopian Farms, Fortune Reports |publisher=Bloomberg |date=12 October 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} In August 2011, President [[Girma Wolde-Giorgis]] of Ethiopia stated that “a substantial investment in agricultural development was key to improving the quality of life across Africa” and that Saudi Star’s investment programme would benefit both Ethiopia and its important trading partner, Saudi Arabia.{{Cite web|url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article481429.ece|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110802000556/http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article481429.ece|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-08-02|title=Ethiopia pledges to work closely with the Kingdom in manpower sector - Arab News|date=2011-08-02|access-date=2018-06-12}} Al Amoudi also owns [[coffee plantation|land used to produce coffee]]. Of the {{convert|2295|ha|acre}} of land acquired by Ethio Agri-CEFT (which he owns) in the [[Sheka Zone]] of Ethiopia, it has only covered 1,010 hectares with coffee and shade trees, with the rest remaining as natural vegetation.{{Cite web|url=http://newbusinessethiopia.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=536:ethiopias-challenge-balancing-agriculture-with-environmental-protection-&catid=28:enviroment&Itemid=51|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016051551/http://newbusinessethiopia.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=536:ethiopias-challenge-balancing-agriculture-with-environmental-protection-&catid=28:enviroment&Itemid=51|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-10-16|title=Ethiopia’s Challenge: Balancing Agriculture with Environmental Protection {{!}} NewBusinessEthiopia|date=2011-10-16|access-date=2018-06-12}} In 2011, he donated 10 million birr (US$500k) to the proposed Ethiopian National Coffee Museum in Ethiopia’s Kaffa Zone.{{Cite web|url=http://www.waltainfo.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=25334&Itemid=134|title=Walta Information Center|website=www.waltainfo.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-12}} In September 2011, in response to an appeal from Prime Minister [[Meles Zenawi]] for popular support for the financing of the [[Renaissance Dam]] in North West Ethiopia which will triple the country’s hydro-electric power, Al Amoudi pledged a donation of 1.5bn birr (around US$88m).{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsdire.com/news/2124-ethiopia-al-amoudi-pledges-15-billion-br-for-renaissance-dam.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927231547/http://www.newsdire.com/news/2124-ethiopia-al-amoudi-pledges-15-billion-br-for-renaissance-dam.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-09-27|title=Ethiopia: Al-Amoudi pledges 1.5 Billion Br. for Renaissance dam » Ethiopian News - Everything that Happens!|date=2011-09-27|access-date=2018-06-12}} ==Kidnapping and Detention== {{Main article| 2017 Saudi Arabian purge}} On 4 November, 2017, Mohammed Hussein Al Amoudi was kidnapped upon the orders of Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman(MBS) and detained in [[Saudi Arabia]] in a supposed "corruption crackdown" conducted by Mohammed Bin Salman's royal anti-corruption committee.{{Cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/factbox-saudi-arabia-detains-princes-ministers-in-anti-corruption-probe-1.2118958|title=Factbox: Saudi Arabia detains princes, ministers in anti-corruption probe|last=|first=|date=2017-11-05|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=2017-11-08}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.argaam.com/en/article/articledetail/id/513047|title=Saudi Arabia arrests 11 princes, 38 ministers in corruption probe|last=|first=|date=2017-11-05|website=[[Argaam]]|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/saudi-ministers-national-guard-economy-dismissed-171104190619900.html|title=Saudi Arabia princes detained, ministers dismissed|website=www.aljazeera.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-arrests/saudi-billionaire-prince-alwaleed-detained-in-corruption-inquiry-idUSKBN1D506P|title=Future Saudi king tightens grip on power with arrests including Prince Alwaleed|last=Kalin|first=Stephen|last2=Paul|first2=Katie|date=2017-11-05|website=[[Reuters]]|publisher=|access-date=2017-11-07}}{{Cite web|url=http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/5636723881001/|title=Corruption crackdown in Saudi Arabia|last=|first=|date=2017-11-06|website=[[Fox Business]]|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-08}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/04/billionaire-saudi-prince-alwaleed-bin-talal-arrested-in-corruption-crackdown-local-reports.html|title=Billionaire Saudi Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal arrested in corruption crackdown|last=David|first=Javier E.|date=5 November 2017|website=[[cnbc]]|publisher=|access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/saudi-princes-former-ministers-arrested-in-apparent-power-consolidation-1509837798|title=Saudi Princes, Former Ministers Arrested in Apparent Power Consolidation|last=Stancati|first=Margherita|date=2017-11-05|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=2017-11-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105000022/https://www.wsj.com/articles/saudi-princes-former-ministers-arrested-in-apparent-power-consolidation-1509837798|archive-date=2017-11-05|dead-url=yes|last2=Said|first2=Summer|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660|last3=Farrell|first3=Maureen}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/04/world/middleeast/saudi-arabia-waleed-bin-talal.html|title=Saudi Arabia Arrests 11 Princes, Including Billionaire Alwaleed bin Talal|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David D.|date=2017-11-04|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2017-11-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} This was done on the authority of Crown Prince [[Mohammad Bin Salman]]. Al-Amoudi has not been seen since his abduction and detention, and it is feared that he is being tortured to force him to transfer his wealth to Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman. It is also possible that he could have been murdered. Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed had tried to secure his release, but was unsuccessful. ==Philanthropy== Al Amoudi has committed funds to support healthcare and sport in Saudi Arabia, the US, Europe and Africa.{{cite web|url=https://www.sheikhmohammedalamoudi.info/ |title=Official Web Site - Sheikh Al Amoudi | Authorized & Official |publisher=Sheikhmohammedalamoudi.info |date= |accessdate=12 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.economistinsights.com/speaker/3145|title=Sheikh Mohammed Hussein Al Amoudi|publisher=Economist Insights |date= |accessdate=20 May 2016}} He funded a [[breast cancer]] research centre at [[King Abdulaziz University]].{{Cite web|url=http://archive.arabnews.com/?page=1|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616061137/http://archive.arabnews.com/?page=1|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-06-16|title=Arab News Newspaper|date=2012-06-16|access-date=2018-06-12}} In 2008, Al Amoudi funded King Saud University’s an [[enhanced oil recovery]] research chair.[http://enews.ksu.edu.sa/2011/06/29/alamoudi-chair-enhanced-oil-recovery/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323025053/http://enews.ksu.edu.sa/2011/06/29/alamoudi-chair-enhanced-oil-recovery/|date=23 March 2012}} He also fully funded the King Abdullah Institute for Nanotechnology at [[King Saud University]].[https://archive.is/20130210100817/http://www.zawya.com/Story.cfm/sidZAWYA20101213035404/1st%20nanotechnology%20institute%20in%20KSA%20to%20be%20launched%20on%2011-11-11] Al Amoudi was named as one of the [[William J. Clinton Foundation]] Donors, according to information released as part of an obligation placed on former [[Bill Clinton|President Clinton]] when he supported [[Hillary Clinton]]'s nomination as Secretary of State. He is reported to have donated between US$5m and US$10m to the foundation.{{cite web |url=https://apple.news/AaeO83PbKNCSae41afdwmKA |title=Fact-checking donations to the Clinton foundation |publisher=PolitiFact.com |date=7 July 2016 |accessdate=12 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510154417/https://apple.news/AaeO83PbKNCSae41afdwmKA |archive-date=10 May 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Al Amoudi sponsored the [[CECAFA Cup]], Africa's oldest football cup competition, in 2005 and 2006, the tournament was named the Al Amoudi Senior Challenge Cup as a result in those years.{{Cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201009061000.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100909174814/http://allafrica.com/stories/201009061000.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-09-09|title=allAfrica.com: Rwanda: Challenge Cup Preps on Course - Musonye|date=2010-09-09|access-date=2018-06-12}} He also supports Ethiopian Premier League Club [[Saint George S.C.]]{{cite web|author=Markos Berhanu |url=http://www.ethiosports.com/2010/11/29/ethiopia-football-can-giuseppe-dossena-end-saint-george%e2%80%99s-misery |title=Ethiopia Football: Can Giuseppe Dossena end Saint George’s Misery? |publisher=Ethiosports |date=29 November 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} and covered the medical expenses of one of Ethiopia’s most celebrated footballers, [[Mengistu Worku]],{{cite web|author=Solomon Amare |url=http://www.ethiosports.com/2010/12/08/ethiopia-football-legendary-player-coach-mengistu-worku-returns-home |title=Ethiopia Football: Legendary Player & Coach Mengistu Worku returns home |publisher=Ethiosports |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} before his death in December 2010. In 2011, he pledged 100 million [[Ethiopian birr]] for a stadium and access road in [[Mek'ele]].{{cite web|author=Markos Berhanu |url=http://www.ethiosports.com/2011/01/04/ethiopia-football-sheikh-al-amoudi-donates-100-million-birr-for-mekelle-stadium-road-project |title=Ethiopia Football: Sheikh Al Amoudi donates 100 million birr for Mekelle Stadium & road project |publisher=Ethiosports |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} In January 2017, The Sheikh Mohammed Hussein Ali Al-Amoudi Stadium was opened.{{cite web|last1=Berhanu|first1=Markos|title=Sheikh Mohammed Al-Amoudi Stadium to be Inaugurated on January 14|url=http://www.ethiosports.com/2016/12/21/sheikh-mohammed-al-amoudi-stadium-to-be-inaugurated-on-january-14/|website=Ethiosports|accessdate=20 April 2017}} The Stadium reportedly cost more than $22 million, and took four and a half years to complete.{{cite web|last1=Berhanu|first1=Markos|title=Sheikh Mohammed Al-Amoudi Stadium to be Inaugurated on January 14|url=http://www.ethiosports.com/2016/12/21/sheikh-mohammed-al-amoudi-stadium-to-be-inaugurated-on-january-14/|website=Ethiosports|accessdate=20 April 2017}} ==Defamation actions== In December 2010 Al Amoudi initiated a claim in the English [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] against [[Elias Kifle]] of the Washington, D.C.-based ''[[Ethiopian Review]]'' claiming damages for [[libel]]. In July 2011 Kifle was ordered to pay £175,000 in damages for publishing false information.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14345007 | work=BBC News | title=Ethiopian billionaire wins libel action in UK | date=29 July 2011}} The ''Ethiopian Review'' had also repeated unwarranted material relating to his family and to matters previously dealt with in the ''Al Amoudi v. Brisard'' case of 2005. M. Brisard had made serious and unwarranted allegations concerning engagement in the funding of terrorism in the wake of 9/11 but had subsequently apologised for the accusation. The judge found the statements to be untrue and stated that Al Amoudi "is implacably opposed to terrorism in all its forms”.{{cite web|url=http://www.out-law.com/page-7002 |title=Count the readers before suing for internet libel |publisher=Out-law.com |date=15 June 2006 |accessdate=29 July 2012}} ==Honors and recognition== Al Amoudi has been ranked among the 100 richest people by ''[[Forbes]]'' since 2006, being ranking 82nd on the list in 2015. He was awarded an [[honorary doctorate]] from [[Addis Ababa University]] and has been honoured with the [[Order of the Polar Star]] by [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|King Carl XVI Gustaf]] of Sweden.{{cite web|url=http://www.summitreports.com/pdfs/yemen.pdf |format=PDF |title=Yemen : Moving Forward With Optimism |publisher=Summitreports.com |accessdate=12 August 2015}} Al Amoudi was honoured for his achievements in economics and philanthropy at the 19th Arab Economic Forum Summit in 2011, with special reference to his commitment to sustainable development.{{cite web|url=http://www.midroc-ceo.com/?q=Saudi%20Investor%20Honored |title=Saudi Investor Honored At Economic Forum | MIDROC Ethiopia Technology Group |publisher=Midroc-ceo.com |date=3 June 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2015}} ==Personal life== Al Amoudi was born in the north-central Ethiopian city of Dessie, in Wollo region and brought up in Woldia, a town also in Wollo, Ethiopia. He was born to a father of [[Hadhrami people|Hadhrami]] Yemeni origin and an Ethiopian mother of Wollo Amhara descent. He grew up in Ethiopia, before emigrating to Saudi Arabia with his brother Mauricet and becoming a Saudi citizen. According to the ''BBC'', Al Amoudi splits his residence between central London, Surrey and Saudi Arabia. He is married to Soniat Saleh Selassie Al Amoudi, an Ethiopian and shareholder of MIDROC Construction.{{Cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201007200761.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728212048/http://allafrica.com/stories/201007200761.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-07-28|title=allAfrica.com: Ethiopia: Midroc Replaces Shimeles|date=2013-07-28|access-date=2018-06-12}} They have eight children. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.sheikhmohammedalamoudi.info Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Amoudi, Mohammed Hussein}} [[Category:1940s births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Jeddah]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:Ethiopian businesspeople]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian billionaires]] [[Category:Ethiopian billionaires]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian Muslims]] [[Category:Hadhrami people]] [[Category:Ethiopian people of Yemeni descent]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian people of Ethiopian descent]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian people of Yemeni descent]]

In many countries, a '''municipal commissioner''' is an [[official]] in a [[Municipal corporation|municipal government]] such as that of a [[city]] or a [[town]].
==India== {{main|Municipal Commissioner (India)}} In India, every Municipal Corporation in India is administratively headed by a Municipal Commissioner, who is the de facto head of the municipal corporation, the form of government which is usually granted to a city of more one million in population.
==Sri Lanka== {{main|Municipal Commissioner (Sri Lanka)}} In Sri Lanka, under the ''Municipal Council Ordinance'' there is a municipal commissioner of each municipal council. He/she would be the chief administrative officer and is the highest ranking non-elected officer of the municipality and in most cases be an officer of the [[Sri Lanka Administrative Service]] on secondment. In the absence of the [[Mayor]], the municipal commissioner serves as the chief executive of the municipality and between the end of term of an mayor and election of a new mayor, the municipal commissioner would serve as the officer implementing the powers and function of the municipal council. The common seal of the council is retained by the municipal commissioner. The municipal council may appoint a ''Charity Commissioner of the Council''.<ref name="ord">[http://www.commonlii.org/lk/legis/consol_act/mc576223.pdf Municipal Council Ordinance]</ref>
==Sweden== {{main|List of municipal commissioners for finance of Stockholm}} In Sweden, the municipal commissioners for finance of [[Stockholm]] (finansborgarråd) is often translated as Mayor of Stockholm, because the municipal commissioner for finance has become the top politician of Stockholm municipality since the Stockholm municipal reform 1940.

'''NAXION''' previously known as '''National Analysts Worldwide''', is an American [[market research|marketing research]] company that originally worked as a division of the [[Curtis Publishing Company]]. It was founded by [[Charles Coolidge Parlin]] in 1911. [[Donald M. Hobart]], future head of the division, joined in 1923, though he ended up resigning from the company in 1928 because he desired to work on the selling side of the concept. He was asked to rejoin the company and become the head of the division in 1938 after Parlin had decided to retire.<ref>{{cite journal |author=James Playsted Wood |date=January 1962 |title=Donald M. Hobart |journal=The Journal of Marketing |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=79–80 |publisher=[[American Marketing Association]] |doi= |pmid= |pmc= |jstor=1249638}}</ref> It is considered to be the "first commercial research company" ever formed.<ref>{{cite book |title=Computer-aided marketing and selling: information asset management |last=Shaw |first=Robert |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1991 |publisher=Robert Shaw |location= |isbn= 9780750600705|page=80 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Y8MAEjyztR4C&pg=PA80&dq=%22Charles+Coolidge+Parlin%22#v=onepage&q=%22Charles%20Coolidge%20Parlin%22&f=false |accessdate=December 30, 2010}}</ref> It became an independent organization in 1943 in order to "provide research services to industry and government."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalanalysts.com/about/corporate-history.asp|title=About Us - Corporate History|author=|date=|work=|publisher=National Analysts Worldwide|accessdate=December 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120711020733/http://nationalanalysts.com/about/corporate-history.asp|archivedate=July 11, 2012|df=}}</ref>
== History ==
===As NAXION=== NAXION is the new name for National Analysts Worldwide, a [[market research]]/[[marketing research]] and consulting company.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.naxionthinking.com/about-us/our-history|title=Our History {{!}} NAXION {{!}} Research > Consulting|website=www.naxionthinking.com|access-date=2018-06-21}}</ref> The firm was formed in 1911 when [[Curtis Publishing Company]] hired [[Charles Coolidge Parlin]] to oversee the Division of Commercial Research and conduct research that would help manufacturers understand their customers in the newly emerging [[consumer economy]].<ref>http://www.marketingpower.com/Calendar/Pages/CharlesCoolidgeParlinAward.aspx.</ref><ref>The History of Marketing Thought, Robert Bartels, page 124 - 125.</ref><ref>Market Research and Modeling: Progress and Prospects, Youuram Wind, Paul E. Green, page 246.</ref><ref>History of Qualitative Research Methods in Marketing, page 5.</ref> The goal was to encourage manufacturing companies to make more effective use of advertising in Curtis publications like ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]'' and ''[[The Ladies Home Journal]]'', both of which would go on to have a major impact on 20th Century popular culture. It is considered to be the "first commercial research company" ever formed.<ref>American Advertising Foundation www.advertisinghalloffame.org/members/member_bio.php?memid=748</ref><ref>Marketing/Research People: Their Behind-th-Scenes Stories, Jack J. Honomichl, page 100.</ref><ref>A New Brand of Business, Douglas B. Ward</ref> It became an independent corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Curtis in 1943 in order to "provide research services to industry and government." In 1970, it was purchased by [[Booz Allen Hamilton]],<ref>Original Corporate Records, National Analysts Worldwide, Historical Society of Pennsylvania</ref> a consulting firm then seeking to expand its role in the marketing services arena. Two Booz Allen Hamilton officers, Susan Schwartz McDonald and John Berrigan, purchased the firm in 1992, and with Berrigan's retirement in 2004, ownership was restructured as an [[Employee stock ownership plan|ESOP]] under the leadership of McDonald, CEO. In 2006, the firm changed its name to National Analysts Worldwide. In June 2014, the firm changed its name to NAXION to better reflect its expanding 21st century capabilities and affirm its global reach.
Standard techniques like probability sampling, and concepts like focus groups, were either developed at National Analysts or saw some of their earliest application. Select other contributions to the industry include:
:* modern qualitative research techniques including some of the earliest focus groups on record :* predictive modeling techniques
:* optimization modeling :* hierarchical segmentation models and use of multi-criteria cluster techniques :* sampling techniques including invention of Area Probability Sampling<ref>http://www.nationalanalysts.com/about/research-leadership.asp</ref>
===Today=== More than a full century after its inception, NAXION remains headquartered in Philadelphia, PA, and operating as a hybrid marketing research and consulting firm. It employs 80 professionals full time. It consistently ranks amongst the [[Honomichl Top 50]], the largest U.S. research firms.<ref>http://www.marketingpower.com/ResourceLibrary/MarketingNews/Pages/2010/6_30_10/Honomichl_Top_50.aspx</ref> Industries served include: healthcare, pharmaceuticals, communications, technology, media, energy, financial services, residential design, transportation, B2B and consumer products. Service Capabilities include:
:* Brand Strategy :* Demand Forecasting :* Market Surveillance :* Segmentation :* Product Development :* Pricing :* Market Entry Strategy :* Brand Equity Assessment :* Positioning :* Customer Insight

The '''National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)''' is a private-public non-profit organisation in [[Nigeria]] . The council's mandate is to improve the attractiveness of Nigeria’s economy as a place to do business in the global marketplace.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tonyelumelufoundation.org/pressreleases/national-competitiveness-council-meets-set-agenda-improving-nigerias-business-environment/|title=National Competitiveness Council Meets to set Agenda for Improving Nigeria’s Business Environment|publisher=[[The Tony Elumelu Foundation]]|accessdate=24 June 2014 |date=4 February 2013}}</ref> The Council's operations are largely driven by the private sector, with government playing a supportive and enabling role. The Council serves as a nexus for the dialogue between business, trade unions, regulatory organisations, academia, international development organisations, think tanks, media and the Nigerian Government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nccnigeria.org/our-vision-and-mission/ |title=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)Our Vision and Mission - National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN) |publisher=Nccnigeria.org |date=2013-02-04 |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> The outcome of this dialogue is actionable recommendations and an implementation strategy for policies that will improve competitiveness and collective prosperity for Nigeria's citizens.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fmi.gov.ng/latest/14940/|title=Industrial revolution: Jonathan inaugurates National Competitiveness Council|publisher=Federal Ministry of Information|accessdate=24 June 2014 |date=5 February 2013}}</ref>
==History== The Council was inaugurated by His Excellency [[Goodluck Jonathan|Goodluck E. Jonathan]] on 4 February 2013. Former bank executive Matthias Chika Mordi was appointed as the inaugural chief executive officer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mordi-appointed-chief-executive-of-nccn/159271/|title=Mordi Appointed Chief Executive|publisher=[[Thisday]]|accessdate=25 June 2014|date=18 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921024445/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mordi-appointed-chief-executive-of-nccn/159271|archivedate=21 September 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tonyelumelufoundation.org/pressreleases/nigerian-competitiveness-council-appoints-leading-investment-banker-inaugural-ceo/|title=Nigerian Competitiveness Council Appoints Leading Investment Banker As Inaugural Ceo|publisher=[[The Tony Elumelu Foundation]]|accessdate=24 June 2014 |date=September 2013}}</ref>
==Structure== The Council is chaired by the incumbent Minister of Trade and Investment. The position of vice-chair is held by an appointed private sector leader. The CEO heads the secretariat in charge of the council's executive and administrative tracks.
==Current membership== Membership on the council is by presidential appointment in consultation with the acting Minister of Trade and Investment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nccnigeria.org/leadership-and-governance/ |title=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)Leadership and Governance - National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN) |publisher=Nccnigeria.org |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref>
===List of members=== #'''Dr. [[Olusegun Olutoyin Aganga|Olusegun Aganga]]'''- ''NCCN Chairman'' - Hon Minister, Federal Ministry of Industry, Trade and Investments #'''[[Tony Elumelu|Tony O. Elumelu]]'''- ''NCCN Vice-chairman'' - Founder, [[The Tony Elumelu Foundation]] #'''Chika Mordi'''- ''NCCN CEO'' - Chairman, UBA Capital #'''[[Aliko Dangote|Alhaji Aliko Dangote]]''' - Founder [[Dangote Group]] #'''Prof Austin Esogbue''' - Professor and Director Emeritus School of Industrial and Systems Engineering [[Georgia Institute of Technology]], Atlanta, Georgia #'''Austin Okere''' - Group CEO, Computer Warehouse Group #'''Bola Adesola''' - Managing Director/CEO, Standard Chartered Bank of Nigeria #'''Frank Aibogun''' - Publisher, [[Business Day (Nigeria)]] Newspaper #'''[[Frank Nweke]] II''' - Director General, [[Nigerian Economic Summit Group]] #'''Dr. Issac Okemini''' - AMC Consulting #'''Chief Kola Jamodu''' - President, Manufacturers Association of Nigeria #'''Dr. Nwnanze Okidigbe''' - Chief Economic Advisor to the President #'''[[Omobola Johnson]]''' - Hon. Minister, Federal Ministry of Communication Technology #'''Dr. Saad Usman''' - Director, (Osprey Investments) Emir of Jere #'''Dr. Obadiah Mailafia''' - Chef de Cabinet ACP Group of States Brussels Belgium #'''Oba Nsugbe QC, SAN''' - Joint Head of Pump Court Chambers #'''Yvonne Ike''' - Chief Executive Officer, Renaissance Capital West Africa
===Advisers to the Council=== A cross-section of respected global and Nigerian institutions;.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tonyelumelufoundation.org/programme/national-competitiveness-council-nigeria-nccn/|title=National Competitiveness Council Of Nigeria (NCCN)|publisher=[[The Tony Elumelu Foundation]]|accessdate=24 June 2014 |date=September 2013}}</ref>
#[[Michael Porter|Professor Michael Porter]] of the Harvard Institute for Strategy and Competitiveness #[[Lynda Chalker, Baroness Chalker of Wallasey|Baroness Lynda Chalker]] of the Honorary International Investors Council #Dr. Juan E. Pardinas, Director, of the Mexican Institute for Competitiveness #Dr. Wiebe Boer of [[The Tony Elumelu Foundation]]
==Activities==
===Working groups=== The NCCN initiated four working groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nccnigeria.org/the-nccn-working-groups/ |title=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)The NCCN Working Groups - National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN) |publisher=Nccnigeria.org |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> The working groups draw membership from the NCCN council, the Nigerian private sector, international development bodies and consulting firms. The working groups are set up to develop recommendations and facilitate the implementation of changes to improve Nigeria’s competitiveness and performance in global rankings.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Working group title !! Chairman !! Vice-chair |- | Tax, Trade and Business Enablement<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nccnigeria.org/the-nccn-working-groups/#ttbe|title=Tax, Trade and Business Enablement Working group|publisher=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> || '''[[Aliko Dangote|Alhaji Aliko Dangote]]''' || '''Dr. Issac Okemini''' |- | Human Capital, Innovation and Capacity Building <ref>{{cite news|url=http://nccnigeria.org/the-nccn-working-groups/#hcicb|title=Human Capital, Innovation and Capacity Building Working group|publisher=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> || '''[[Omobola Johnson]]''' || '''Austin Okere''' |- | Security, Corruption and Country Image<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nccnigeria.org/the-nccn-working-groups/#scci|title=Security, Corruption and Country Image Working group|publisher=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> || '''[[Frank Nweke|Frank Nweke II]]''' || '''Frank Aibogun''' |- | Bureaucracy, Titling and Registration<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nccnigeria.org/the-nccn-working-groups/#btr|title=Bureaucracy, Titling and Registration Working group|publisher=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> || '''Chief Kola Jamodu''' || '''Oba Nsugbe QC, SAN''' |}
===National and Sub-National Report=== The National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria’s (NCCN) “National Competitiveness Report” will expand on the framework and methodology used in the World Economic Forum’s – Global Competitiveness Report and the World Bank’s – Doing business report to provide insight into the challenges to improved competitiveness and assess the regulation surrounding the ease with which businesses are able to set up and operate in Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nccnigeria.org/initiative/nccn-national-and-sub-national-report/ |title=National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN)NCCN National and Sub-National Report - National Competitiveness Council of Nigeria (NCCN) |publisher=Nccnigeria.org |date=2014-03-29 |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> The hope is that these reports will focus discourse around competitiveness issues and provide a platform for policy changes that will result in increased competitiveness.

'''Norman Allen Adie''' (born November 25, 1946) is a former theater owner/operator/developer and confessed Ponzi schemer,<ref>[http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/34/50/dtg_heightscinemaponzi_2011_12_16_bk.html Moviehouse Madoff! Former Heights Cinema owner pleads guilty to Ponzi scheme], ''The Brooklyn Paper'', December 13, 2011.</ref> presently inmate number 64354-054 in the Federal Detention Center (FDC) in Miami, Florida.<ref> [http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/LocateInmate.jsp Inmate Locator], ''Federal Bureau of Prisons.''</ref> Born in Scotland, Adie began his career in London with the [[Rank Organization]] and [[Twentieth Century Fox]]<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080509/BIZ/805090368 Monroe Cinema Debuts Today], ''Times Herald Record'', May 9, 2008.</ref> before moving to the United States to work at [[Radio City Music Hall]].
Adie then founded Screen Arts Corporation and developed his own New York theaters in Times Square and Park Slope, Brooklyn.<ref>[http://articles.nydailynews.com/1995-11-14/local/17976594_1_film-industry-player-angelika-film-center-split-personality Theater's Opening Act Nears], ''The New York Daily News'', November 14, 1995.</ref> Adie's decade-long efforts to open a theater in Monroe, New York were delayed by protracted, well-publicized lawsuits and counter-lawsuits resulting from a troubled partnership with One Liberty Properties.<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060318/NEWS/303189997 Building plans still stalled], ''Times Herald-Record'', March 18, 2006.</ref> "Monroe 6 Cinemas" eventually opened in 2008, but went into receivership three years later after Adie failed to pay the mortgage and property taxes.<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110714/BIZ/107140333 Court seizes Monroe 6 profits], ''Times Herald-Record'', July 14, 2011.</ref> Adie operated the Brooklyn Heights Cinema<ref>[http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/31/4/31_04littletheatertoexp.html Little Theater to Expand], ''The Brooklyn Paper'', January 26, 2008.</ref> in Brooklyn, New York, for ten years before selling it in 2011 after misappropriating the theater's finances.<ref>[http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20110603/REAL_ESTATE/110609943 Tainted Brooklyn Heights Cinema sold], ''Crain's New York Business'', June 3, 2011.</ref> Adie opened the Foxmoor 7 Cinemas in Marshalls Creek, Pennsylvania in 2006 only to be evicted in 2009 for failing to pay rent.<ref>[http://www.poconorecord.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20091211/NEWS/912110360 Foxmoor 7 Theater Evicted After Failing to Pay Rent], ''Pocono Record'', December 11, 2009.</ref> Adie's plans to open a movie multiplex in Matamoras, Pennsylvania in 2008 never came to fruition and resulted in a $12.7 million judgment against Adie in 2009.<ref>[http://www.strausnews.com/articles/2010/01/09/pike_county_courier/news/1.txt Movie Magic Gone Bad], ''The Pike County Courier'', January 7, 2010.</ref>
On November 23, 2010, Adie was arrested and charged with Federal securities and wire fraud.<ref> [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/24/nyregion/24arrest.html Theater Owner Is Charged With Fraud], ''The New York Times'', November 24, 2010. </ref> <ref> [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/klyn_cinema_owner_reel_swindler_0aw8tmUDM41aeUjZxQb3GL Brooklyn cinema owner a reel swindler: feds], ''The New York Post'', November 24, 2010. </ref> <ref> [http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/33/48/bh_heightscinema_2010_11_26_bk.html Feds: Heights Cinema owner was Ponzi schemer], ''The Brooklyn Paper'', November 24, 2010. </ref> He confessed to the charges in December, 2011<ref> [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/owner_scheme_brooklyn_heights_cinema_z5TbT1uEKo6uWe1hIUtO3N Ex-owner of Brooklyn Heights Cinema pleads guilty to $500K-plus fraud scheme], ''The New York Post'', December 12, 2011. </ref> and was sentenced in May, 2012 to 20 months in Federal prison.<ref> [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/victim_de_faces_fraudster_nlgUWKWkK746N6ZqGM7ifK Victim ‘de-faces’ fraudster], ''The New York Post'', May 30, 2012. </ref><ref> [http://pikecountycourier.com/article/20120719/NEWS01/120719937/Theater-owner-sentenced-to-20-months Theater owner sentenced to 20 months], ''The Pike County Courier'', July 19, 2012. </ref>

{{no footnotes|date=January 2009}} The '''philosophy of business''' considers the fundamental principles that underlie the formation and operation of a [[business enterprise]]; the nature and purpose of a [[business]], and the [[moral obligation]]s that pertain to it. == Influence == [[Philipp Blom]] summarises the development and impact of business-centric ideas in society prior to the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008 | global financial crisis of 2008]]:
[...] [[Friedrich Hayek | Friedrich von Hayek]] and [[Ludwig von Mises]] [...] were Europeans who had passed their formative years in the chaotic interwar years and whose conclusion was that state intervention and planned economies were hallmarks of dictatorship [...]. They believed that it was healthier to take ideology out of politics and base the workings of society on the objective, nonideological laws of the free market. [...] The [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] cult of reason and of the common good was replaced by the concepts of rationalization and the maximization of profits, which were applied to a reevaluation of social institutions - infrastructure, schools, universities, prisons, health care, and so on - according to business-driven criteria of profitability and cost-effectiveness. Especially in the United States but also increasingly in Europe, we began to run our societies as businesses. Beginning in the late 1970s and gaining speed in the 1980s, this gospel changed and polarized our societies - but it also provided an umbrella of meaning and necessity under which we could hide from challenges from without as well as doubts from within. For many in the West, the idea of the market became their ideological home. Living in accordance with its guiding providence and iron laws created a sense of stability, of virtue even. But 2008 shattered this collective piety and made millions understand that they had been lied to [...]. {{cite book | last1 = Blom | first1 = Philipp | author-link1 = Philipp Blom | title = Fracture: Life & Culture in the West, 1918-1938 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=q1-WBgAAQBAJ | location = London | publisher = Atlantic Books | publication-date = 2015 | page = 408 | isbn = 9780857892201 | accessdate = 2017-01-01 | quote = [...] Friedrich von Hayek and Ludwig von Mises [...] were Europeans who had passed their formative years in the chaotic interwar years and whose conclusion was that state intervention and planned economies were hallmarks of dictatorship [...]. They believed that it was healthier to take ideology out of politics and base the workings of society on the objective, nonideological laws of the free market. [...] The Enlightenment cult of reason and of the common good was replaced by the concepts of rationalization and the maximization of profits, which were applied to a reevaluation of social institutions - infrastructure, schools, universities, prisons, health care, and so on - according to business-driven criteria of profitability and cost-effectiveness. Especially in the United States but also increasingly in Europe, we began to run our societies as businesses. Beginning in the late 1970s and gaining speed in the 1980s, this gospel changed and polarized our societies - but it also provided an unmbrella of meaning and necessity under which we could hide from challenges from without as well as doubts from within. For many in the West, the idea of the market became their ideological home. Living in accordance with its guiding providence and iron laws created a sense of stability, of virtue even. But 2008 shattered this collective piety and made millions understand that they had been lied to [...]. }}

[[ARM Cement Limited]] }} '''Pradeep Paunrana''' (born 1959) is a [[businessman]], [[entrepreneur]], [[industrialist]] and [[philanthropist]] in [[Kenya]], the largest economy in the [[East African Community]]. He is the current [[Managing Director]] of [[ARM Cement Limited]], one of the leading cement manufacturers in Eastern Africa.{{cite web| url=http://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/meet-the-boss-pradeep-paunrana-managing-director-arm-cement/35185/|title=Meet The Boss: Pradeep Paunrana, Managing Director, ARM Cement|first=Dinfin| last=Mulupi|date=7 February 2014|accessdate=17 October 2014| publisher=HowWeMadeItInAfrica.Com}} ==Background and education== He was born in 1959 and was educated in Kenyan schools. He attended [[New York University Stern School of Business]] (NYU Stern), graduating in 1983, with the degree of [[Master of Business Administration]] (MBA). His father, the late ''Harjivandas J. Paunrana'', who had dropped out of school at age 13, made sure his son received a good solid education.{{cite web| url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/949d03ac-2f5e-11e4-83e4-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3GQ9jMU3E|title=Kenya’s ARM Cement Comes Through A Mix of Fortunes|first=Katrina|last=Manson|date=9 September 2014|accessdate=17 October 2014|newspaper=[[The Financial Times]] (London)}} ==Career== From 1983 until 1984, Pradeep worked at a software company in New York,{{Cite news|url=https://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/meet-the-boss-pradeep-paunrana-managing-director-arm-cement/|title=Meet the Boss: Pradeep Paunrana, managing director, ARM Cement|date=2014-02-07|work=How We Made It In Africa|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en-US}} earning US$40,000 annually. He returned to Kenya in 1984, at the age of 24 at the request of his father who handed him the keys to the business in exchange for a percentage ownership, but no salary. Pradeep, therefore became the [[Managing Director]] of ''Athi River Mining Limited'', as the company was known at the time. From annual sales of KSh6 million (approx.US$70,000) in 1984, the business has grown to annual sales of KSh14 billion (approx.US$160 million), in 2014. In 1994, the company which started with manufacturing fertilizer, animal feeds, ceramics, glass and plastics, began making cement for the first time. In 2007, the company which had changed names to '''[[ARM Cement Limited]]''' listed its shares on the [[Nairobi Securities Exchange]] (NSE). Over the years, the company has grown into the largest manufacturer of cement in East Africa, producing 2.6 million tonnes annually. Pradeep Paunrana, personally owns 18% of the company shares, making him one of the wealthiest individuals in Kenya.{{cite web| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Pradeep-Paunrana/-/1248928/1990146/-/item/0/-/kq4sgv/-/index.html| title=It All Started With A Bunch of Keys|first=Jackson|last=Biko| date=12 September 2013|accessdate=17 October 2014|newspaper=[[Nation Media Group|Business Daily Africa]] (Nairobi)}}{{cite web| url=http://mobile.nation.co.ke/business/Who-are-Kenya-s-wealthiest-/-/1950106/2113702/-/format/xhtml/-/lis6h6z/-/index.html|title=Who Are Kenya's Wealthiest?|date=16 December 2013|first=Wangui| last=Maina|accessdate=17 October 2014|newspaper=[[Nation Media Group|Business Daily Africa]] (Nairobi)}} ==Other responsibilities== Pradeep Paunrana is a married father of four, three daughters and one son. He is the current Chairman of the Kenya Association of Manufacturers. ==See also== *[[Indian diaspora in East Africa]] *[[List of African millionaires]] *[[List of wealthiest people in Kenya]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.armafrica.com/?page=contact_us Webpage of ARM Cement Limited] {{DEFAULTSORT:Paunrana, Pradeep}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Kenyan people of Indian descent]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kenyan people of Gujarati descent]] [[Category:Kenyan philanthropists]] [[Category:Kenyan business executives]] [[Category:Stern School of Business alumni]]

{{Economic systems sidebar|coordination}} In [[economics]], a '''price system''' is a component of any [[economic]] system that uses [[prices]] expressed in any form of [[money]] for the [[Economic value|valuation]] and distribution of goods and services and the [[factors of production]]. Except for possible remote and primitive communities, all modern societies use price systems to allocate resources, although price systems are not used exclusively for all resource allocation decisions.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/475822/price-system | title = Price system | author = [[George J. Stigler]], [[William J. Baumol]] | work = [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] | accessdate =2 January 2018}}</ref>
A price system may be either a [[regulated market|fixed price system]] where [[Administered price|prices are administered]] by a government body, or it may be a [[free price system]] where prices are left to float "freely" as determined by supply and demand uninhibited by regulations. A mixed price system involves a combination of both administered and unregulated prices.
== History == Price systems have been around as long as there has been [[money]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}}
The price system has evolved into the system of global [[capitalism]] that is present in the early 21st century.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110728152736/http://www.technocracy.org/archives/185-langan I Am The Price System R. B. Langan Great lakes Technocrat April 1944, # 66.]</ref> The Soviet Union and other [[Communist state]]s with a centralized [[planned economy]] maintained controlled price systems. Whether the ruble or the dollar is used in the economic system, the criterion of a price system is the use of money as an arbiter and usual final arbiter of whether a thing is done or not. In other words, few things are done without consideration for the monetary costs and the potential making of a profit in a price system.
=== Debate on socialism === {{See also|Socialist calculation debate}} The American economist [[Thorstein Veblen]] wrote a seminal tract on the development of the term as discussed in this article: ''The Engineers and the Price System''.<ref>Harbinger Edition, 1963. LCCCN 63-19639. First Published as a series of essays in [[The Dial]] (1919) then as a book in 1921.</ref><ref>[http://www.faculty.rsu.edu/~felwell/Theorists/Veblen/Papers/Engineers.htm Full Text (HTML)]</ref> Its chapter VI, ''A Memorandum on a Practicable Soviet of Technicians'' discusses the possibility of [[socialist]] revolution in the United States comparable to that then occurring in Russia (the Soviets had not yet at that time become a state (USSR formed in 1922)).
The original conception of socialism involved the substitution of money as a unit of calculation and monetary prices as a whole with [[calculation in kind]] (or valuation based on natural units), with business and financial decisions replaced by engineering and technical criteria for managing the economy. Fundamentally, this meant that socialism would operate under different economic dynamics than those of capitalism and the price system.<ref>{{cite book |last= Bockman|first= Johanna |title= Markets in the name of Socialism: The Left-Wing origins of Neoliberalism|publisher= Stanford University Press|year= 2011|month= |isbn= 978-0-8047-7566-3|page = 20|quote= According to nineteenth-century socialist views, socialism would function without capitalist economic categories - such as money, prices, interest, profits and rent - and thus would function according to laws other than those described by current economic science. While some socialists recognized the need for money and prices at least during the transition from capitalism to socialism, socialists more commonly believed that the socialist economy would soon administratively mobilize the economy in physical units without the use of prices or money.}}</ref>
In the 1930s, the economists [[Oskar Lange]] and [[Abba Lerner]] developed a comprehensive model of a socialist economy that utilized a price system and money for the allocation of [[capital good]]s. In contrast to a free-market price system, "socialist" prices would be set by a planning board to equal the [[marginal cost]] of production to achieve [[Neoclassical economics|neoclassical]] Pareto efficiency. Because this model of socialism relied upon money and administered prices as opposed to non-monetary calculation in physical magnitudes, it was labelled "market socialism". In effect, Oskar Lange conceded that calculations in a socialist system would have to be performed in value terms with a functioning price system rather than using purely natural or engineering criteria as in the classic concept of socialism.<ref name="Revisiting the Socialist Calculation Debate">''Revisiting the Socialist Calculation Debate: The role of markets and finance in Hayek's response to Lange's challenge'', by Auerbach, Paul and Sotiropoulos, Dimitris. 2012. Kingston University London, Economics Discussion Paper 2012-6, pp. 1-2: "He readily acceded to the need for efficiency calculations to be made in value terms rather than using purely natural or engineering criteria, but claimed that these values could emerge along lines consistent with neoclassical value theory, without the need for a market in capital goods and without private ownership over the means of production."</ref>
===Hayek=== {{details|Price signal}} [[Austrian School]] economist [[Friedrich Hayek]] argued that a free price system allowed economic coordination via the [[price signal]]s that changing prices send, which is regarded as one of his most significant and influential contributions to economics.<ref>{{ Citation | last = Skarbek | first = David | title = F. A. Hayek's Influence on Nobel Prize Winners | journal = [[Review of Austrian Economics]] | volume = 22 | number = 1 | date = March 2009 | url = http://www.davidskarbek.com/papers/HayekNobel.pdf }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In "[[The Use of Knowledge in Society]]" (1945), Hayek wrote, "The price system is just one of those formations which man has learned to use (though he is still very far from having learned to make the best use of it) after he had stumbled upon it without understanding it. Through it not only a [[division of labor]] but also a coördinated utilization of resources based on an equally divided knowledge has become possible. The people who like to deride any suggestion that this may be so usually distort the argument by insinuating that it asserts that by some miracle just that sort of system has spontaneously grown up which is best suited to modern civilization. It is the other way round: man has been able to develop that division of labor on which our civilization is based because he happened to stumble upon a method which made it possible. Had he not done so, he might still have developed some other, altogether different, type of civilization, something like the "state" of the termite ants, or some other altogether unimaginable type."<ref name="Hayek45">{{cite journal |url=https://www.kysq.org/docs/Hayek_45.pdf |author=[[Friedrich Hayek]] |title=The Use of Knowledge in Society |date=September 1945 |journal=The American Economic Review |volume=35 |number=4 |page=528}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Rank Xerox | logo = rank xerox logo.png | type = | caption = | fate = Acquired | successor = Xerox | foundation = 1956 | defunct = 1997 | location = | industry = Office equipment | key_people = | products = | num_employees = | parent = [[Xerox]] Corp., The [[Rank Organisation]] | subsid = }}
'''Rank Xerox''' was formed in 1956 as a [[joint venture]] between the [[Xerox]] Corporation of United States (a.k.a. Haloid Photographic) and the [[Rank Organisation]] of the United Kingdom, to manufacture and market Xerox equipment initially in Europe and later in Africa and Asia. A further joint venture between Rank Xerox and Modi Group in India formed '''Modi Xerox''' (now [[Xerox India]]) to manufacture and sell Xerox equipment in the [[Indian subcontinent]].
==History== The initial joint venture was 50% Xerox and 50% Rank Organisation, but this changed after a few years to a 60/40 split. Later, Xerox bought a further share making the split 80/20, and in the late 1990s, completed the purchase, so Rank Xerox formally became Xerox.
In 1956 the Rank Organisation was looking for a product to sit alongside a small business it had making camera lenses. Thomas Law, who was the head of the business, found his answer in a scientific magazine he picked up by chance. He read about an invention that could produce copies of documents as good as the original.<ref>Daily Telegraph, 7 June 1997.</ref> Law tracked down the backers, an obscure photographic-supply company in Rochester, New York, named Haloid.
Haloid and Rank subsequently formed an affiliate called Rank Xerox (Rank put up £600,000 for a 50% stake in Rank Xerox). This arrangement paved the way for Xerox factories in Great Britain and a sales and distribution system that brought Xerox machines to the European market. As photocopying took the world by storm, so did Rank’s profits. According to Graham Dowson,later Rank’s chief executive, it was "a stroke of luck that turned out to be a touch of genius … If Tom Law had not seen that magazine, we would not have known about xerography – or at least not before it was too late."<ref>Daily Telegraph, 13 January 1995.</ref>
In 1968, Rank Xerox under Nigel Foulkes, initiated a marketing concept to sell rather than rent their copying machines behind the [[Iron Curtain]], by appointing Gordon S Planner as General Manager East Export Operations via a firm of head hunters.<ref>'Marketing' September 1970 page 50, item by Paul Zentner</ref> Sales of machines increased rapidly to Eastern Europe and a unique marketing concept deployed in 1973 using a specially built and equipped train showcasing Rank Xerox copiers, it toured nine countries in Eastern Europe covering 30,000 miles and returned orders of over £3m.<ref>'Financial Times' 5 January 1976. 'Capitalist Tools in the Communist Office' item by Roy Levine.</ref> Commissioning London based designer Cairnes Maltby, the latter came up firstly with a train unit comprising five cars. These contained staff accommodations, a kitchen, overnight staff sleeping cabins and a demonstration salon and bar. Pulled by engines of the various countries of the Soviet Bloc, the train reached Russia and a welcome market. The following year Cairnes Design Associates produced the first of the Rank Xerox Showliners. A large, articulated, semi-trailer truck with motorised pull-outs, this allowed the road legal trailer to extend to a, fully functional showroom, complete with large picture windows and small kitchen. Unlike the train it was capable of reaching the small to medium size cities of the Soviet Bloc. Both train and truck avoided the problems that affected western firms trying to establish a presence in the East.
Later, in the UK, the mobile exhibition concept was taken to its ultimate conclusion. Following several truck based Showliners, a train and a converted bus, a huge mobile exhibition was conceived. This moved from town to town, like a circus, using sports halls and exhibition centres to present a vast, virtual, [[office of the future]]. Ralph Land CBE, was General Manager of Rank Xerox Eastern Europe Operations (1976–91).
During the 1980s the managing director Roland E. Magnin helped the company to become the international arm of Xerox Corporation. He then moved to the corporation's headquarters in Connecticut where he was responsible for the decentralization program of the company as one of its top directors.
The remaining 20% stake owned by the Rank Organization in Rank Xerox was bought out by the parent Xerox Corporation for ₤940 million in 1997.<ref name="1997-10k">{{cite web |url=http://getfilings.com/o0000108772-98-000006.html |title=Form 10K filing for Xerox Corporation, Fiscal Year 1997 |publisher=[[Securities and Exchange Commission]] |date=1998 |accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> The Rank Xerox name was discontinued following the buyout, and the Rank Xerox Research Centre was renamed to the Xerox Research Centre Europe.
==Awards== * Rank Xerox was the first winner of the [[European Quality Award]] in 1992. * Rank Xerox was the first sponsor of [[Southampton F.C.]] from 1980 until 1983. * Rank Xerox was the first sponsor of [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] in 1983.

{{globalize|article|the United Kingdom|date=March 2012}} A '''scheme of arrangement''' (or a "scheme of reconstruction") is a court-approved agreement between a [[corporate law|company]] and its [[shareholder]]s or [[creditor]]s (e.g. lenders or [[debenture]] holders). It may affect mergers and amalgamations and may alter shareholder or creditor rights.
Schemes of arrangement are used to execute arbitrary changes in the structure of a business and thus are used when a reorganisation cannot be achieved by other means. They may be used for rescheduling debt, for takeovers, and for returns of capital, among other purposes.
In the United Kingdom, the relevant provisions for effecting a scheme of arrangement are found in the [[Companies Act 2006]], Part 26 (ss.895-901) and Part 27 (special rules for public companies).
In Australia, the relevant provisions for effecting a scheme of arrangement or reconstruction are located in Part 5.1 of the [[Corporations Act 2001]] (Cth).
In South Africa, the relevant provisions for effecting a scheme of arrangement are found in the Companies Act 2008, No. 71 Of 2008, Sections 114 and 115.

{{Infobox officeholder |name=Ujwal Thapa |native_name=उज्वल थापा |image= Ujwal Thapa.jpg |caption= Ujwal Thapa at press release |party= [[Bibeksheel Sajha Party]] |occupation= youth leader and activist, entrepreneur and social worker |website={{URL|http://www.whynepal.com}} {{URL|http://www.leadnepal.com}} }} '''Ujwal Thapa''' ({{lang-ne|उज्वल थापा}}) is a Nepalese youth leader and activist, entrepreneur and social worker. He is the president of youth party [[Bibeksheel Nepali]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.leadnepal.com/team/ujwal-thapa/|title=Team – Ujwal Thapa – BibekSheel Nepali|publisher=En.leadnepal.com|accessdate=2018-06-12}}</ref> He has been leading [[Bibeksheel Nepali]] in which different youth staged protests at [[Maitighar Mandala]] in support of senior orthopaedic surgeon of [[Tribhuwan University]] [[Institute of Medicine, Nepal|Maharajganj Teaching Hospital]] Dr. [[Govinda K.C.]] who has been in fast-unto-death for reforms in Medical Sector.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/hundreds-demonstrate-support-dr-govinda-kc/|title=Thousands demonstrate in support of Dr Govinda KC|work=[[The Himalayan Times]]|date=2016-07-23|accessdate=2018-06-12}}</ref> He also led a symbolic protest against members of [[Legislature Parliament of Nepal]] at [[Baneshwor]], [[Kathmandu]] demanding affordable medical facilities for the citizens.<ref>{{cite web|author=Milan Poudel|url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2016-07-21/youths-stage-symbolic-protest-against-601-mps-photo-feature.html|title=Youths stage symbolic protest against 601 MPs (photo feature) - Capital|work=The Kathmandu Post|date=2016-07-21|accessdate=2018-06-12}}</ref>
He along with another [[Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist)|CPN-UML]] youth leader Yogesh Bhattarai has demanded youth issues to be focussed in the upcoming local level election.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/youth-activists-draw-attention-parties-poll-agendas/|title=Youth activists draw attention of parties to their poll agendas|work=The Himalayan Times|date=2017-04-09|accessdate=2018-06-12}}</ref>
He had participated as an independent candidate in the [[Nepalese Constituent Assembly election, 2013]] from Kathmandu Constituency Number 5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://election.ujyaaloonline.com/candidates/2310/Ujwal-Thapa/|title=Candidate – Ujwal Thapa |publisher=Election.ujyaaloonline.com|accessdate=2017-04-14|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414081856/http://election.ujyaaloonline.com/candidates/2310/Ujwal-Thapa/|archivedate=2017-04-14}}</ref>
==Agriculturalist and entrepreneur== In 2002, he developed Max Digital Solutions, a website development and software branding business. The '''University of Sydney Business School''' is the business faculty and a constituent body of the [[University of Sydney]]. It was established in January 2011 and formed from the School of Business within the previous Faculty of Economics and Business. The former combined faculty itself descended from the original Faculty of Economics founded in 1920, which was the first faculty of its kind in Australia.
In 2017, the Business School’s MBA program was ranked number one in Australia by the biennial [[Australian Financial Review]] BOSS Magazine MBA Rankings <ref>http://www.afr.com/brand/boss/mba-rankings-2017-the-best-mba-courses-in-australia-20170830-gy72jz</ref>. In the same rankings, the Executive MBA program was ranked number one in Australia in 2013 and 2015, and third in 2017 <ref>http://www.afr.com/brand/boss/mba-rankings-2017-the-best-executive-mba-courses-in-australia-20170904-gyaa7n</ref>. In 2018, the [[QS World University Rankings]] ranked the University of Sydney in the top 20 in the world in accounting and finance and top 40 in business and management studies. The University of Sydney has been ranked number one in Australia and fourth in the world for graduate employability in the 2017 and 2018 QS Employability Rankings <ref>https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/employability-rankings/2018</ref>. In 2017, The Economist and the Financial Times ranked the Business School number one in Australia for Master of Management <ref>https://www.ft.com/content/6b52615a-8694-11e7-8bb1-5ba57d47eff7</ref>. The program has been ranked number 25 in the world and number two in the Asia-Pacific region, and number one in the world for career progress of the program’s graduate, by the [[Financial Times]]. The Economist also ranked the program number 3 in the Asia-Pacific region, and number 35 in the world <ref>http://www.economist.com/whichmba/MiM/2017/Ranking</ref>. The CEMS Master’s in International Management program, the only Australian CEMS member, was ranked ninth in the world in 2017 by the [[Financial Times]].
The School was the first in Australia to receive accreditation by the [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB)<ref>[http://www.aacsb.edu/General/InstLists.asp?lid=3 Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business - Schools Accredited in Business] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070222080454/http://www.aacsb.edu/General/InstLists.asp?lid=3 |date=2007-02-22 }}, retrieved on 2008-01-15.</ref> and the [[European Quality Improvement System]] (EQUIS) from the [[European Foundation for Management Development]].<ref>[http://www.efmd.org/html/Accreditations/link_overview.asp?id=040929sqku&tid=4&ref=ind European Quality Improvement System Accredited Members] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080127175806/http://www.efmd.org/html/Accreditations/link_overview.asp?id=040929sqku&tid=4&ref=ind |date=2008-01-27 }}, retrieved on 2008-01-15.</ref> It is also the only Australian business school to become an Associate member of the [[Global Alliance in Management Education]] (CEMS).<ref>[[CEMS - The Global Alliance in Management Education|- Global Alliance in Management Education]], retrieved on 2011-08-10.</ref>
==History== {{Refimprove section|date=January 2017}}
Established in 1920, the Faculty of Economics initially offered the Bachelor of Economics degree which commenced in 1914. The postgraduate Master of Economics degree commenced in 1925.
In 1985 the faculty introduced its second undergraduate and postgraduate degree programs, the Bachelor of Economic and Social Sciences and the Master of Economic and Social Sciences, respectively.
In 1993 its third undergraduate degree program, the Bachelor of Commerce, was introduced. The Master of International Studies followed in 1994, the Master of Commerce in 1995 and the Master of International Business in 1999.
In 2005 the Business School ended its association with the jointly run [[Australian Graduate School of Management]] with [[The University of New South Wales]].
From 2006 to 2007, the University conducted a review of its social sciences faculties. As a result of that review, it was determined that parts of the School of Economics within the Faculty of Economics and Business were to be transferred to the Faculty of Arts (as it then was). In January 2008, the disciplines of Government & International Relations and Political Economy were transferred to the Faculty of Arts. In January 2011, the Discipline of Economics, the Centre for International Security Studies and the Graduate School of Government were also transferred to the Faculty of Arts, which was renamed the [[University of Sydney Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences|Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences]]. Concurrently, the remaining disciplines of the Faculty of Economics and Business formed the University of Sydney Business School.
On 30 July 2009, the Business School announced the launch of the Global Executive MBA program, which was commenced in February 2010.
On 30 July 2012, the Business School announced the introduction of the Sydney Master of Business Administration (MBA) program,<ref>http://www.afr.com/p/national/education/sydney_mba_seven_year_hitch_ends_UOD4HBh6ljCb9h1aW0iRUO</ref> with the program starting February 2013. Particular emphasis has been put into making positioning it as an internationally recognised degree.<ref>http://www.afr.com/p/national/education/university_of_sydney_makes_new_mba_GZe2AXeSKyOXCT7m4UyAsO</ref>
In 2013, the purpose-fitted CBD campus, providing a central location for participants in the part-time MBA program, was opened.
In 2016, the Abercrombie Building was opened by The Hon. Gladys Berejiklian MP, Treasurer of NSW and Minister for Industrial Relations, and Deputy Liberal Leader. <ref>http://www.mbanews.com.au/inside-university-sydney-business-school-abercrombie/</ref>
In 2017, the Business School launched a new full-time MBA program for 2018 entry. <ref>https://sydney.edu.au/news-opinion/news/2017/08/14/the-traditional-mba-is-dead--declares-university-of-sydney-.html</ref>
==Organisation== The Dean of the Sydney Business School is Professor Gregory Whitwell.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sydney.edu.au/business/about/dean|title=Dean's Welcome|website=sydney.edu.au|language=eng|access-date=2017-01-19}}</ref>
Disciplines within the school include: * [http://sydney.edu.au/business/accounting/ Discipline of Accounting] * [http://sydney.edu.au/business/information_systems/ Discipline of Business Information Systems] * [http://sydney.edu.au/business/business_law/ Discipline of Business Law] * [http://sydney.edu.au/business/finance/ Discipline of Finance] * [http://sydney.edu.au/business/international_business/ Discipline of International Business] * [http://sydney.edu.au/business/marketing/ Discipline of Marketing] *[http://sydney.edu.au/business/business_analytics Discipline of Business Analytics] * [http://sydney.edu.au/business/wos/ Discipline of Work and Organisational Studies]
In addition to these, the school also offers postgraduate programs and research through its Centre for International Security Studies, Institute of Transport and Logistics Studies, Workplace Research Centre and Graduate School of Government.<ref>[http://sydney.edu.au/business/org/ University of Sydney Business School - Organisation], retrieved on 2008-01-15.</ref>
==Professional accreditation== Studies in accounting are recognised by [[CPA Australia]] and the [[Chartered Accountants Australia and New Zealand]] (CAANZ).
Majors in Industrial Relations and Human Resource Management can be accredited by the Australian Human Resource Institute (AHRI).
An extended major in Business Information Systems can be accredited by the [[Australian Computer Society]].<ref>[http://www.econ.usyd.edu.au/2387.html Quality Assurance and Professional Accreditation - Faculty of Economics and Business], retrieved on 2008-01-15.</ref>
The Master of Marketing program is accredited by the [[Australian Marketing Institute]] (AMI).
Through the Bachelor of Commerce (Finance major), the University is recognised as a program partner with [[CFA Institute]].

==Alumni== Alumni of the Sydney Business School or its predecessor faculties include: * [[Glenn Stevens]], <small>BEc (Hons) 1979</small>, economist and Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia <small>(2006—)</small> * [[Tony Abbott]], <small>BEc 1979 (Syd), LLB 1981 (Syd), MA 1982 (Oxford)</small>, Australian Liberal politician and former Prime Minister of Australia * [[Anthony Albanese]], <small>BEc 1984</small>, Australian Labor politician and former Deputy Prime Minister of Australia * [[Chris Bowen]],<small>BEc</small>, Australian Labor politician * Roger Davis - <small>BEc</small>,Chairman of [[Bank of Queensland]] * [[Nick Greiner]], <small>BEc (Hons)</small>, Australian Liberal politician and former premier of New South Wales <small>(1988–1992)</small> * [[Morris Iemma]], <small>BEc</small>, Australian Labor politician, and former premier of New South Wales <small>(2005–2008)</small> * Justice [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]], <small>BEc</small>, Justice of the [[High Court of Australia]] (1996–2009) * [[Mark Latham]], <small>BEc</small>, former Australian Labor politician, leader of the Australian Labor Party and opposition leader of Australia <small>(2003–2005)</small>
